advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>"With the Alice, change the level without changing the computer"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD (MAR. 86)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said<br><br><font color="#666666"> The electric typewriter's days are numbered. Because now there's a machine that put real wordprocessing power within everyone's reach.<br> The Amstrad PCW 8256 is a complete word-processor and a powerful computer in one unit.<br> And it's unbelievably low price includes a screen with built-in disc drive, keyboard, printer and word processing software...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (APRIL 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"You're never so well served than by yourself..." <br><br> "...create your own micro-server on Thomson."</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>>  GERMAN LEAFLET #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Preliminary/New product leaflet. For exhibitions only<br><br><br> "The new Personal Computer from SHARP - particularly developed for personal use."<br><br> Note the optional Quick Disc drive.<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Pravetz Apple II compatible technology and price are compared with the IBM compatible Pravetz 8C.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Bojidar Stefanov</b> for the English translation</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The advert says:<br><br> <font color ="#666666">The Altos ACS8000-6 series. It's a barrier breaker in every sense. Our entry level, single-user, hard-disk system with floppy backup is priced under $10,000...<br> ... With MP/M at the helm, your Altos system can support up to four simulteneous users with 48 KB RAM each plus 58 MB of Winchester storage and 4 MB of floppy backup. And that adds up to the first microcomputer to give you the power and performance of a minicomputer.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LAST SALES</strong></font><br><blockquote>In July 1985, California Digital sold the Tano at $99. The price would decrease down to $35 while stock last.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Christian Hart for this scan</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT #4(1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The users featured in the ad said:<br><br> (left) <i>Programming is a snap! I'm halfway through Apple's BASIC manual and already I've programmed my own Star Wars game.</i><br><br> ...with half of the universe<br><br> (middle) <i>Those math programs I wrote last week - I just rewrote them using Apple's mini assembler and got them to run a hundred time faster.</i><br><br> Of course, it's very easy for a newbie programmer to program maths assembly routines with a microprocessor which only knows how to add and subtract integer values.<br><br> (right)<i>Apple's smart peripherals make expansion easy. Just plug'em it and you are ready to run. I've already added two disks, a printer and a communication card.</i></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> STRONG WOOMAN(1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Don't beleive this advert!<br> Please, look carefully at the quite horizontal shoulders of the woman who carries the Osborne (about 12 Kg). Either she is a champion of wrestling, or the Osborne case is empty. <br><br> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">You know about computers. In fact, you probably own one now. One that you might be thinking of expanding. We have a better idea. Take a giant step into the personal computing future with an amazing, new C4P from Ohio Scientific...<br><br> ...The C4P is an outstanding premium computer - years ahead of the market. We know because there's nothing quite like it for the price, anywhere. And probably won't be for a very long time.</font> <br><br> About the DISPLAY paragraph:<font color="#666666"><br> "256 x 512 effective graphic points"<br><br></font> <b>Kurt Vogel</b> rectifies:<font color="#666666"><br> The C4P did NOT have a 256x512 graphics mode! If it had, that would have been amazing for the price way back then. Instead, it had a 32x64 character display and claimed that because each character was made up of a 8x8 grid that that was supposed to count as 256x512 graphics. Even given that they used an extended 8 bit character set that included special line and shape characters, you were NEVER able to address indivual pixels!</font> </blockquote>

computer.builtInGames: Model RL-H7000 : 1 x 360k floppy + optional second floppyModel RL-H7000W : 2 x 360k floppy drives
computer.colors: Monochrom (built-in 9 inch CRT green display) and 4 colors (CGA) with external monitor
computer.description:
This is a luggable IBM-PC compatible system. It tends to offer an all-in-one solution for the perfect 80's business man. Back in 1983 it was the first Japanese computer completely IBM-PC compatible (hardware & software).
It has a built-in thermal printer (80/132 columns, 8.5'' wide) using paper-rolls. This was quite useful where you were on the move, but the weight of the whole system is also quite impressive. It is maybe transportable but surely not portable ! It was also possible to connect a more sophisticated printer through the Parallel port. There is a 9'' CRT green display built-in along with a brightness control. An interesting feature is that you can also connect the Sr Partner to an external color monitor, thus unleashing the fantastic power of this ultra-modern laptop...err. Maybe not, but you can at least enjoy CGA color graphics (640 x 200 with 4 colors, wow).
Apparently there were several models with different storage configurations : one 5''1/4 disk-drive (360k), two 5''1/4 disk-drives, one disk-drive and one hard-disk (10Mb, 20Mb)...
On the original disk, the MS-DOS ver 2.0A and Basic v2.0 were delivered.
Presented at the Las-Vegas Comdex in november 1983, the Senior Partner was proposed for 2495$ with Wordstar, Visicalc, PFS-File, PFS-Graph, PFS-Report and GW-Basic.
Panasonic, along with National and Technics were brands owned by the Matsushita japanese group.
computer.graphics: CGA graphics :320 x 200 (4 colors), 640 x 200 (2 colors)
computer.keyboard: Full-stroke QWERTY keyboard with numeric keypad and function keys
computer.media: Model RL-H7000 : 1 x 360k floppy + optional second floppyModel RL-H7000W : 2 x 360k floppy drives
computer.name: Senior Partner
computer.ports: Serial/RS232c, Centronics/Parallel, 1 x ISA expansion slot, RAM expansion slot, RGB monitor ouput
computer.power: Built-in PSU. Doesn't work with any fuse less than 20 Amp !...

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> BUILT-IN PRINTER</strong></font><br><blockquote>This thermal printer uses paper-rolls and can print on 80 or 132 columns (8.5'' wide).</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> CLOSED</strong></font><br><blockquote>Once closed the Senior Partner can be easily...err well...transported ?!</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR</strong></font><br><blockquote>Once the door is opened it reveals several connectors and some room to store the power cord. <br><br> From left to right :<br> - RS232c<br> - Parallel/Printer<br> - RGB video out (CGA)<br> - Power plug<br> - ON/OFF switch<br> - Fuse. </blockquote>
